author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Another Week, Another Philharmonic Podium Candidate
description: Santtu-Matias Rouvali is the latest potential music director to lead the orchestra, in a program of Zibuokle Martinaityte, Strauss and Tchaikovsky.
content: Jakub Hrusa and Santtu-Matias Rouvali, two of the world’s most respected rising maestros, keep ending up in close proximity. In 2017 they were simultaneously named the principal guest conductors of the Philharmonia Orchestra in London. (Rouvali was elevated to that ensemble’s top post two years later.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Makiko Inoue
title: Curling Drifts to the East, Where Rock Stars Are Being Born
description: In recent years, Japan, China and South Korea have embraced the sport, investing resources, creating celebrities and changing the competitive landscape.
content: BEIJING — In Japan, the curlers of Team Fujisawa, the women’s team, are rock stars. Their cries of “sodanee,” or “OK,” across the curling rink have become a buzzword. Their snacking habits were once national news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko, Anton Troianovski and Shashank Bengali
title: Russia sends mixed signals as tensions rise.
description: KYIV, Ukraine — Tensions between Russia and the West ratcheted up on Friday as Moscow announced plans to test nuclear-capable missiles and held war games on NATO’s doorstep in Belarus, while the United States said more Russian forces continued to take positions menacing Ukraine in a crisis that risks erupting into the biggest conflict in Europe in decades.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Tensions between Russia and the West ratcheted up on Friday as Moscow announced plans to test nuclear-capable missiles and held war games on NATO’s doorstep in Belarus, while the United States said more Russian forces continued to take positions menacing Ukraine in a crisis that risks erupting into the biggest conflict in Europe in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark C. O'Flaherty
title: Fashion’s Favorite London Canteen
description: The Rocha family — Max, Simone, John and Odette — opens a restaurant.
content: LONDON — A few days before her London Fashion Week show, Simone Rocha, a designer of fantastical and romantic women’s wear, was at Café Cecilia, a stark white restaurant next to a canal and Victorian gasworks in the East London borough of Hackney. She was taking a quick break with her husband, the cinematographer Eoin McLoughlin, and her parents, John and Odette Rocha.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Todd Plummer
title: Pickleball Is Ready for Prime Time
description: As the sport continues to gain popularity, companies are looking to cash in.
content: There’s a moment in the most recent season of “Curb Your Enthusiasm” when the character Hal Berman (Rob Morrow), seeking support for his ill father, tells Larry David that the point of country clubs is to feel a sense of togetherness in a time of need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Unraveling Booster and Vaccine-Timing Rules for International Travelers
description: The requirements for entering foreign countries during the pandemic can be confusing and ever-changing, especially when it comes to boosters. Here’s what to expect.
content: John Henretta had been looking forward to his June hiking trip to Switzerland for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: You Just Can’t Tell the Truth About America Anymore
description: The teaching of history is under siege.
content: There is a dangerous censoriousness pulsing through American society. In small towns and big cities alike, would-be commissars are fighting, in the name of a distinct minority of Americans, to stifle open discussion and impose their views on the community at large. Dissenters, when they speak out, are hounded, ostracized and sometimes even forced from their jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: Why didn’t Alexandra Trusova’s quads deliver gold? Skating scoring explained.
description: Trusova had the most ambitious technical program, but the result of a figure skating competition is the combined score of the short and long programs.
content: Alexandra Trusova, the 17-year-old Russian prodigy, won the free skate on Thursday after attempting five quadruple jumps in the most ambitious technical program in the history of women’s Olympic figure skating. But she had to settle for the silver medal and appeared extremely upset afterward. So what happened?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Texas Voting Law Leads to Jump in Ballot Application Rejections
description: Texas Republicans said the state’s new voting law would make it “easy to vote, hard to cheat.” County election officials say it’s sowing confusion ahead of next month’s primaries.
content: Thousands of Texans have had their absentee ballot applications denied as a result of regulations put in place under the state’s new election law, a jump in rejections that could force many older and disabled voters to either vote in person or not at all in primary elections early next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Giddy, Terrifying Siege of Ottawa
description: Pandemic misery has swelled the ranks of a right-wing protest.
content: OTTAWA — When I asked Matthew Wall, a 36-year-old electrician from Manitoba, what brought him to this city, which has been overwhelmed by a giant protest encampment, he answered with one word: “Mushrooms.” Searching for his purpose in life, he said, he went on a psychedelic spiritual journey and had an image of the Freedom Convoy, a demonstration against Covid rules that has converged on the Canadian capital with trucks and other large vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: The United States’ Message to Russia: Prove Us Wrong
description: “If Russia doesn’t invade Ukraine, then we will be relieved that Russia changed course,’’ Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said at the United Nations.
content: MUNICH — President Biden and his top aides acknowledge they are risking American credibility as they constantly renew the alarm that Russia is only “several days” away from triggering an unprovoked land war in Europe that could kill tens of thousands of Ukrainians in its opening hours, and plunge the world back into something resembling the Cold War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: A Critique of Government That Progressives — Myself Included — Need to Hear
description: The economist  Alex Tabarrok discusses the public choice theory of government failure.
content: Government is a bureaucratic, slow-moving institution. It’s too easily captured by special interests. It’s often incapable of acting at the speed and scale our problems demand. And when it does act, it can make things worse. Look no further than the Food and Drug Administration’s slowness to approve rapid coronavirus tests or major cities’ inability to build new housing and public transit or Congress’s failure to pass basic voting rights legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: 50 Years Later, the Rothko Chapel Meets a New Musical Match
description: Tyshawn Sorey’s “Monochromatic Light (Afterlife),” written for the chapel’s anniversary, is a tribute to the first music performed in the space.
content: Before Tyshawn Sorey composed a note of his latest work, commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Rothko Chapel in Houston, he spent hours inside its octagonal temple containing more than a dozen dark canvases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Buckley
title: P.J. O’Rourke and the Death of Conservative Humor
description: P.J. O’Rourke was a fellow of infinite jest.
content: “How many feminists does it take to change a light bulb?” my friend P.J. O’Rourke asked me one less-than-sober evening years ago. The answer was “One — and that’s not funny!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Diana Nguyen, Eric Krupke, Liz O. Baylen, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: ‘Somebody’s Got to Save Us While We’re Saving Everybody Else’
description: Burned out and exasperated, many nurses are quitting the profession, leaving the U.S. health system with a critical shortage.
content: As hospitals in the United States battled another coronavirus wave in the past few months, another crisis was steadily growing more acute: a shortage of nurses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Ship Carrying 1,100 Porsches and Other Luxury Cars Is Burning and Adrift
description: A fire broke out Wednesday morning in the cargo hold of the ship, which departed from Emden, Germany, on Feb. 10 and was headed to Davisville, R.I.
content: A mammoth cargo ship believed to be carrying thousands of vehicles including 1,100 Porsches was on fire and drifting off the coast of the Azores on Thursday after its 22 crew members were rescued from the vessel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: A Quiet Exit for a ‘SPAC king’
description: Chamath Palihapitiya, a prolific sponsor of blank-check funds, is stepping down as chairman of Virgin Galactic.
content: Virgin Galactic announced today that Chamath Palihapitiya, whose SPAC took the space tourism company public three years ago, has stepped down as its chairman. It’s a low-key and sudden departure for the outspoken financier, and another sign of the bad times that have hit the market for blank-check funds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: As Gale Made an Extreme Sport of Heathrow Landings, He Called the Plays
description: Jerry Dyer became a media sensation after filming, and commenting on, planes landing at the London airport during a howling storm.
content: LONDON — As a winter gale with 70-mile-per-hour wind gusts tore across the British Isles on Friday, the government warned everybody to stay inside. But one man, Jerry Dyer, ventured out to a blustery field at the end of Runway 27L at Heathrow Airport to capture live footage of planes trying to land in the howling storm.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jennifer Haigh on ‘Mercy Street’
description: Haigh talks about her new novel, and Megan Walsh discusses “The Subplot: What China Is Reading and Why It Matters.”
content: Jennifer Haigh’s new novel, “Mercy Street” — which Richard Russo calls “extraordinary” in his review — is about a woman named Claudia who works at a women’s clinic in Boston. It’s also about the protesters outside. On this week’s podcast, Haigh says the novel was inspired in part by her own time working on a clinic’s hotline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel
title: DraftKings recruits fewer bettors than expected, despite freebies.
description: The company said it lost $326 million in the fourth quarter and told investors to expect nearly $1 billion in additional losses from operations this year.
content: It was impossible to watch this year’s Super Bowl without being bombarded with ads for online sports betting services, as the industry seized on a wave of states legalizing its business to capture new customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Madeleine Ngo
title: The Fed rolls out tough trading restrictions following a scandal.
description: Top Federal Reserve officials will be barred from owning many securities after a trading scandal and a series of prominent resignations.
content: The Federal Reserve on Friday adopted a new set of ethics rules meant to prevent questionable financial market trading activity by top officials, a sweeping response to a scandal that has rocked the central bank since late last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Santa Clara County Tackles Children’s Covid-19 Grief
description: More than one in 330 children in California have lost a parent or other at-home caregiver to Covid-19.
content: As California looks toward a new, hopefully more normal chapter of the pandemic, I’ve found myself stuck on an unsettling statistic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘What Is Black Love Today?’
description: In this lesson, students will read Modern Love essays that explore how Black people live and love in this moment. Then, they will write about what love looks like in their families or communities.
content: Featured Series: “What Is Black Love Today?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Back to Working from Work
description: What do return to office plans look like post-Omicron?
content: With visions of endemicity dancing in their heads, executives and managers a are eyeing fresh return-to-office plans — for the fourth time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Up in a Tree
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Art Cooley, a Founder of the Environmental Defense Fund, Dies at 87
description: He was part of a small group of scientists and citizens on Long Island that was instrumental in banning the toxic pesticide DDT, first locally and then nationally.
content: Art Cooley, a high school biology teacher who was part of a small band of people whose concerns about issues like the toxicity of the pesticide DDT led them in the late 1960s to start the Environmental Defense Fund, which went on to become one of the nation’s largest environmental organizations, died on Jan. 30 in hospice care in Grand Junction, Colo. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi and Julian E. Barnes
title: Wife of Navy Nuclear Engineer Pleads Guilty in Submarine Spy Case
description: Diana Toebbe, a high school teacher, acknowledged her part in an effort to try to sell nuclear reactor secrets her husband had taken from the Navy.
content: MARTINSBURG, W.Va. — The wife of a Navy nuclear engineer pleaded guilty on Friday to taking part in a conspiracy to sell submarine secrets to a foreign country, bringing to a close an espionage case that mixed spycraft and politics with the travails of a suburban family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Mevorach
title: ‘How Much of My Story Am I Supposed to Share?’
description: When a former stripper marries a future minister, she goes silent about her past — for a while.
content: My husband and I married in a Presbyterian church in Watkins Glen, N.Y., on the banks of Seneca Lake. It was June 2006, three months before he started seminary and five-and-a-half years after I had quit the sex industry. I considered our wedding the marriage of the former stripper and the future minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tacey Rychter and Isabella Kwai
title: ‘Fortress Australia’ Has a New Message: Come Back
description: For nearly two years, the country projected a harsh message of rigidity and “rules are rules.” Will long-haul travelers bet on the easygoing, inviting image it is sending out now?
content: Moments after the Australian government announced that it would reopen the country’s borders to international travelers later this month, Emily Barrett locked in a fare for a flight to Sydney. The 32-year-old nanny from Palo Alto, Calif., spent three days researching and talking to Australian friends before she decided to book her trip to the island continent, which for two years had some of the world’s strictest border controls and longest lockdowns aimed at controlling the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anderson Tepper
title: New International Fiction, From Ecuador to Zimbabwe
description: Recent novels from around the world include “Jawbone,” “Woman Running in the Mountains,” “The History of Man” and “The Wind Whistling in the Cranes.”
content: JAWBONEBy Mónica OjedaTranslated by Sarah Booker264 pp. Coffee House. Paper, $16.95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: ‘The Former Stripper and the Future Minister’
description: Plus: The Modern Love College Essay Contest is back!
content: Amy Mevorach got married three months before her husband started seminary and five and a half years after she had quit the sex industry. She viewed their wedding as the “marriage of the former stripper and the future minister.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘How Beautiful We Were’ and ‘No One Is Talking About This’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: FAKE ACCOUNTS, by Lauren Oyler. (Catapult, 272 pp., $16.95.) In the days after Donald Trump’s presidential election in 2016, a blogger discovers her boyfriend has been secretly living a second life online as a right-wing provocateur. “Fake Accounts,” our reviewer, Katie Kitamura, noted, is “an invigorating work, deadly precise in its skewering of people, places and things.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Vladimir Putin: Crafty Strategist or Aggrieved and Reckless Leader?
description: Analysts puzzling over the Russian leader’s intentions say that his troop buildup around Ukraine could be a convincing bluff, but also posit that he could have fundamentally changed during the pandemic.
content: MOSCOW — At this moment of crescendo for the Ukraine crisis, it all comes down to what kind of leader President Vladimir V. Putin is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Members of Congress Should Not be Trading Stocks, Ever
description: There is bipartisan support for this popular, common-sense reform.
content: Americans are in a sour mood with their elected officials. Blame the pandemic or inflation or Trumpism or stress or structural problems like inequality, but people do not feel that the system, much less its leaders, are working for them. The nation is experiencing a crisis of confidence that is eating away at its strength and unity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery
title: Austin Police Officers to Be Indicted for Conduct in Racial Justice Protests
description: During demonstrations after George Floyd’s murder, several people in the Texas capital were taken to hospitals after being struck with beanbag rounds that officers fired from shotguns.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — A Texas district attorney said on Thursday it was very likely that several Austin police officers would be indicted on criminal charges for their treatment of protesters who were denouncing police violence and racial injustice after George Floyd was murdered by Minneapolis law enforcement in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman, Dana Rubinstein and Michael Gold
title: New York City Plans to Stop Homeless People From Sheltering in Subway
description: The plan calls for stricter enforcement of transit system rules and more mental-health services and housing options for those being cleared from stations and trains.
content: Mayor Eric Adams and Gov. Kathy Hochul announced on Friday an aggressive plan to deploy police officers and mental-health workers into New York City’s subway, pledging to remove more than 1,000 homeless people who shelter there regularly, some of whom have contributed to escalating violence and harassment in the system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers, Paul Mozur and Jeff Kao
title: Bots and Fake Accounts Push China’s Vision of Winter Olympic Wonderland
description: The country’s propagandists have used a variety of tools online to promote a vision of the Games that is free of rancor or controversy.
content: This article is published with ProPublica, the nonprofit investigative newsroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryce Covert
title: This Is the Difference Between a Family Surviving and a Family Sinking
description: It doesn’t have to be this hard.
content: Last summer the vast majority of American families with children saw money appear in their bank accounts without doing anything at all. Thanks to legislation passed by Democrats earlier in the year, an expanded Child Tax Credit automatically sent out $300 each month through the rest of the year for every child under 6 and $250 for older ones to people who regularly file taxes. It showcased what government can do when it works at its most efficient: seamlessly deliver meaningful benefits without requiring people to take much, or really any, action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: U.S. prime-time broadcast coverage includes the final events for Alpine and freestyle skiing.
description: The two-time Olympic gold medalist Mikaela Shiffrin will compete as part of the Alpine skiing team event.
content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Friday with the final events in Alpine skiing and freestyle skiing. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janelle Zara
title: A Panel Etched with ‘Blood,’ ‘Nerves’ and ‘Knee’
description: Nikita Gale’s new series presents a range of words that might be used to describe a human being.
content: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-seen work by a Black artist and offers a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at “Body Print: Blood” (2022), one of six inscribed aluminum panels in a series by Nikita Gale. The pieces appear in “End of Subject,” Gale’s new solo exhibition, on view at Manhattan’s 52 Walker gallery through March 26.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Tackling Environmental Racism Without Mentioning Race
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, February 18, 2022.
content: “When you look at the most powerful predictor of where the most industrial pollution is, race is the most potent predictor.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Red Covid, an Update
description: The partisan gap in Covid deaths is still growing, but more slowly.
content: Ocean County, in central New Jersey, is a mixture of beach towns like Barnegat Light and exurban towns like Toms River and Lakewood. Household income in the county exceeds the U.S. average.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Hong Kong delays an election amid a Covid surge as leaders ‘focus on the epidemic.’
description: Carrie Lam, the chief executive, said the vote would be postponed until May 8.
content: Hong Kong will postpone the election of its next leader so that it can focus on containing a surge in coronavirus cases driven by the Omicron variant, the city’s chief executive said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Phil Mickelson’s Support of Saudi-Backed Tour Is On Brand for Him
description: Mickelson, one of the game’s most popular players, has simultaneously spent nearly three decades vexing the sport’s leadership, while collecting nearly $100 million in earnings.
content: It is hardly a surprise that Phil Mickelson is playing the provocateur in the growing drama over a proposed, breakaway Saudi Arabia-backed golf league that hopes to lure top professional golfers from the long-established PGA Tour. Mickelson, one of the game’s most popular players, has simultaneously spent nearly three decades vexing the sport’s leadership, whether it has been the august United States Golf Association or the PGA Tour, from whom Mickelson has collected nearly $100 million in career earnings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: How Much of Your Life Do You Share Online?
description: Will, Jada, Jaden and Willow Smith have disclosed personal details of their family life online. What are you willing and unwilling to post?
content: How much of your personal life do you share online?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: A.D.H.D. Can Strain Relationships. Here’s How Couples Cope.
description: The symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder can push couples to their breaking point, but there is hope for those willing to seek help.
content: When Chris Lawson began dating Alexandra Salamis, the woman who would eventually become his partner, he was “Mr. Super Attentive Dude,” he said, the type of guy who enjoyed buying cards and flowers for no reason other than to show how much he loved her.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Eating Lab-Grown Meat and the Return of Segmented Sleep: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Brady Leman of Canada will try to defend his 2018 title in the men’s ski cross.
content: Follow our live coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Why Chinese Americans Are Talking About Eileen Gu
description: The critical crossfire Ms. Gu has faced has implications that go far beyond the Olympic slopes, Chinese Americans say. And some see themselves in the duality she has embraced.
content: When it comes to Eileen Gu, the 18-year-old Olympic gold medalist freestyle skier who was born in San Francisco but competed for China, Chinese Americans have lots of opinions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: California State University Chancellor Resigns After Report He Mishandled Complaints
description: Joseph Castro announced on Thursday that he would resign, a decision that came amid concerns over how he handled sexual misconduct allegations while he was president of Fresno State.
content: The head of the California State University system, the largest four-year higher education system in the country, announced on Thursday that he was resigning, effective immediately. The chancellor, Joseph I. Castro, 55, did not give a specific reason for the decision, which came amid allegations that he had mishandled sexual harassment complaints against an administrator while he was the president of Fresno State University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: At 80, Tamara Moskvina Is Still Going for the Standing Ovation
description: In five decades as a coach, she has prodded — sometimes literally — four skating pairs to Olympic titles. She stands a good chance to be part of a fifth gold medal in Beijing.
content: Weeks before the Soviet Union dissolved in December 1991, Tamara Moskvina, the world’s most renowned coach of pairs figure skating, met with American reporters at a competition in Albertville, France, where the 1992 Winter Olympics would soon be held.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: These Tax Laws ‘Make Scofflaws of Us All’
description: Twenty-four states require you to file a return even if you sent just a single work email while there.
content: Congratulations, road warrior. Last year you did business in five states in a week — emails from airports, phone calls from taxis, videoconferences from hotel rooms, business meals here and there. Later, when you took vacation in yet another state, you flipped open your laptop now and then to check in with colleagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Unable to Agree on Russia Sanctions Bill, Senate Settles for a Statement
description: A bipartisan push to pass the “mother of all sanctions” collapsed after Republicans insisted on imposing broad penalties before an invasion and Democrats, backing the White House, refused.
content: WASHINGTON — For weeks, as President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia signaled he was moving closer to invading Ukraine, members of Congress in both political parties vowed that the Senate would pass a “mother of all sanctions” bill targeting Moscow that would prove the overwhelming, bipartisan American resolve to stand with Kyiv against Russian aggression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah: Russia Loves Playing Chess
description: Noah said Russia has been preparing to play chess while Americans “love dumb games now,” poking fun at a preference for Wordle.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: When are the Olympics over?
description: The closing ceremony is scheduled for Sunday. The Winter Paralympics will open on March 4 and end on March 13.
content: After nearly three weeks of athletes from around the world competing in one of the biggest international sporting events, the Winter Olympics in Beijing are nearing the end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Can I Still Wear Low-Rise Jeans?
description: A reader wants to know whether she has matured past a trend that is back in style.
content: The question of age-appropriate clothing and what exactly that means is complicated and highly personal, but it comes at some point for us all. I remember sitting in an Yves Saint Laurent show about a decade ago watching a model strut around in a tuxedo shorts jumpsuit and high heels and thinking first: Oh, what a great look, I should get that, it will solve all the problems of a minidress; and then, second: Actually, if middle-aged you wears that, you will be the ultimate mutton-dressed-as-lamb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Melissa Eddy
title: Multinationals in Ukraine are ready for a conflict but staying put.
description: Despite warnings by Western leaders of an imminent Russian attack, U.S. and European companies say they see a low risk of an invasion.
content: Big American and European companies operating on the ground in Ukraine said Friday that they had contingency plans at the ready in case of a Russian invasion but so far had not ordered the relocation of employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Eduardo Medina
title: A Fall From the Society Pages to Prison Unsettles Greenwich
description: The sealing of the case against Hadley Palmer, 53, who must register as a sex offender for secretly filming minors, has revived questions about judicial favoritism for the wealthy. Lawyers say they were trying to protect her victims.
content: GREENWICH, Conn. — In a place where it is difficult to stand out among the secluded mansions, Birkin bags and Mercedes-Benz G-Wagons, one woman has drawn unwanted attention this week to one of America’s wealthiest bastions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Lemire
title: Literary LPs
description: Classic albums reimagined as classic books.
content: Can you recognize the albums bearing the names of these famous books and authors?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Kim Potter Sentenced to 2 Years in Prison for Killing Daunte Wright
description: Ms. Potter fatally shot Mr. Wright after drawing her gun instead of her Taser during a traffic stop near Minneapolis.
content: The former police officer who fatally shot Daunte Wright during a traffic stop was sentenced to two years in prison on Friday, far less than the standard of about seven years for manslaughter, after a judge said leniency was warranted because the officer had meant to fire her Taser and not her gun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir, Ian Austen, Richard Pérez-Peña and Vjosa Isai
title: Police in Ottawa Mobilize for an ‘Imminent’ Crackdown on Protest
description: After weeks of truckers and others blocking border crossings and streets in the capital city, the demonstrations appeared to be nearing an end.
content: [Follow our live coverage of the Ottawa Protests.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Amanda Holpuch
title: Storm Eunice Slams Northern Europe With Dangerously High Winds
description: A 122-mile-per-hour gust was recorded in England, where one weather official said the storm would be the worst the country had seen in 30 years. At least seven deaths were reported.
content: LONDON — Strong winds battered parts of Britain and Northern Europe on Friday, as a severe storm led to the deaths of at least seven people in the region, damaged buildings and severely disrupted travel by air, land and sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: A Pair of Diamond-Encrusted Leopards From David Webb’s Menagerie
description: The gold and platinum cage earrings — also set with emeralds and black enamel — were inspired by the jewelry designer’s 1960s-era sketches.
content: Born in 1925 in North Carolina, the jewelry designer David Webb grew up idolizing his grandfather, an engraver, and at 14 began apprenticing under his uncle, who was a jewelry maker. Three years later, Webb left the South to make a name for himself in Manhattan, where the brand was officially established in 1948 with a shop on West 46th Street. By the late ’50s, Webb, who collected children’s books on wild beasts and made weekly pilgrimages to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to study Scythian and ancient Egyptian gold artifacts, had become best known for his enameled animal pieces. Banishing barnyard and household creatures from his jewels, the designer, who died in 1975 at the age of 50, favored a far more exotic and mythical menagerie of big cats, zebras, frogs and more. His creations — from compacts shaped like tortoises to carved coral bracelets inspired by the Hindu makara sea dragon — were coveted by the likes of Elizabeth Taylor, Diana Vreeland and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and were, as one society reporter wrote, “as essential as the food and drink at La Grenouille to the fashion society clan.”

content: “TELL ME, MUSE, of the dinners, much-nourishing and many in number.” So wrote the Greek poet Matro of Pitane in the fourth century B.C., stealing the exalted opening of the “Odyssey” (“Tell me, Muse, of the man of many ways”) for his “Convivium Atticum” and memorializing in epic hexameter a tale in which there are no heroes, only eaters, and no perils to overcome, just food upon food, in mocking homage to the “Iliad” ’s catalog of ships massed for Troy: loaves “whiter than snow”; 13 “very fat” ducks; an eel the length of nine tables; and so many fish and of such kind and season as would have been impossible to serve all at once.
